column62: I have a number of undergraduate researchers (typically 3-6 per semester) who all work on computational projects. Depending on the project, the required skills vary. For most of them, I guide them through using a Unix shell as a first step. Some end up programming in Python -- usually they are already somewhat familiar with it (and certainly with programming) but gain experience with numerical and scientific packages. Some run large numerical simulations on our high performance computer.

column114: Only 1 out of 3 students on average had prior coding experience. This was overcome by having students work in groups, such that at least 1 group member had coding experience.
column115: Modeling of projectile motion with air resistance using python. Students had to accurately predict the motion of a foam rocket based on experimental measurements of muzzle velocity and drag coefficient. In three separate semesters, students were able to do this.
column150: Specific courses will attempt to implement a computational element. Honors intro courses should at least describe how a computational method should proceed, and show worked examples. Mid-level courses should show examples of computational exercises to provide visualization, or solutions to non-analytically solvable problems. We consider it important to note that many problems (e.g., air resistance, EM fields) can be solved to arbitrary accuracy with computation even though analytic solutions are lacking. Insight into a problem doesn't end when a pencil can't solve the problem exactly.

column160: A few courses in programming, but I have been dabbling in programing since age 10. I routinely employ simple computational models in my research. Many close friends are programmers, and we exchange knowledge. While I am an experimentalist, I discuss and collaborate routinely with my computational colleagues on research projects, such that we both understand the basis of each other's work.

column20: Computational tools such as EXCEL are used in the undergad labs. For research involvement studennts use C++ coding and the ROOT analysis package.
column62: I require the use of computational tools in laboratory classes or classes with a lab component. I combine this with lectures on basic data analysis techniques. The main tool is EXCEL. In my experience many students are challenged by even this basic tool. In order to avoid overload I do not go beyond that. Students involved in research of my group need to learn basic C++ coding in order to use ROOT (CERN data analysis package). This is achieved by providing analysis templates and one-on-one instruction by me or one of the postdoctoral assistants.

column62: I try to bring computational examples into intro courses that haven't had them before. Especially problems that are very easy to do computationally that a traditional curriculum ignores - like air resistance in projectile motion. 10 lines of python, very intuitive, extraordinarily practical, but we never taught it because you couldn't solve it with a pencil.
column114: Faculty don't know how to code. They don't want to learn. The faculty that do know how to code don't like change, or being bothered.  I.e., the usual things.  To the extent the have been overcome: hiring younger people, wearing down older ones .  There are no technical barriers present.
column115: I have managed to use python simulations successfully in 100-level physics courses, particularly for simulating the effects of air resistance on projectile motion. One key aspect was that they had to model the motion of real projectiles (nerf darts) and verify the results. It wasn't abstract.   They had to measure velocities, estimate drag coefficients, etc., and use code to finally predict how to hit real, live targets. This made the computation less abstract - they were predicting something physical they could verify.   The fact that it worked convinced other faculty members to include simulations in their own intro- and upper-level courses.   I have had less success when the experimental verification is not included (e.g., E&M). Without checking their simulations against the real world, it is just a game to them.  Finally, this requires group work. I estimate ~1 in 3 of our intro students, even in an honors class, has any prior programming experience. Thus, groups of 3-4 are required to be sure they have the skills to even get started. For upper level courses this is somewhat better, but not as much as you would like.

column62: I'm the Physics department chair and we have a course titled, "Computational Methods in the Physical Sciences" where we use Matlab and Mathematica.  This course is taught in the 3rd semester and used in physics and astronomy courses through the 8th semester (i.e., graduation).
column114: In the early days, the main challenge was to get a site license.  However, because we are a STEM school (Engineering programs, Space Physics, Astronomy, Cyber Security, etc.) that was not a major hurdle.  More and more of our classroom space is being converted to accommodate desktop computers so they can be used in the course of lectures, or homework study sessions.
column115: I introduced Mathematica in my physics lectures and physics labs, and students quickly picked up on the utility of the software.  They were able to explore the solutions homework problems (physics lectures) and acquire a working understanding of statistics (physics labs).  We formally teach Matlab, and students pick up Mathematica through some of the instructors who use it in the course of their lectures and labs.  I happen to be a "big fan" of Mathematica.
column150: Some of our faculty and undergraduate students work on the LIGO experiment.  We also have astronomers who analyze Hubble data and run simulation programs.  We recently put forth a proposal for "internal funding" for the Prescott Astrophysics Center to pursue computational physics in Astrophysics and General Relativity (e.g., in-flow of gases into black holes, core-collapse supernovae)
column151: We have no plans to change how or whether we are using computation in our undergraduate program.
column152: There was something mentioned earlier in the survey regarding "modeling."  One of the reasons I like using Mathematica is that it allows me to model physical systems.  More than that, I have to "fully understand" the model I'm creating so that it can be programmed.  Furthermore, it focusses my attention on the "figures of merit" that describe the main features of the model.       I believe the pinnacle of physics education occurs when students are capable of modeling and can authenticate their approach to solving a problem.  In order to test these models, computational physics plays a key role.  Students will mature in their reasoning skills and apply their scientific and modeling skills to a host of challenging problems facing science and society.
column160: I had my first (and only) programming course at [University] where I learned Fortran IV (1970).  An IBM360 was donated to our college from [Identifying Information] across the street.  I continued my education at [University] where I worked in experimental particle physics (1970-1979).  I learned assembler language and Mathematica on my own because I needed them for my research work.      I started an undergraduate Space Physics program at Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University (Prescott, AZ), and included Computational Methods as a required course in our curriculum.  While I find that only 10% of the incoming students have any programming skills, most of them are quick to pick it up if properly supported and motivated.

column152: I teach at a community college. The current shift mandated by our accrediting agency (ACCJC) is strongly focused on "compliance behavior" and the associated bureaucracy. This makes it very hard to implement significant changes in curriculum since any change needs to go through a committee, have updated student learning outcomes, be mapped to the overall program, and have an assessment plan in place before we attempt anything new. While this bureaucracy means well, faculty are well aware of the work involved in making any significant shift in curriculum. Also, our accrediting agency has a reputation for swift an severe punishment for minor deviations in accreditation standards, so our administration really does pay attention to the details at the course level.

column152: Computational work in this survey doesn't seem to be differentiated, so perhaps in future surveys you might consider questions aimed at different levels. column181: I put a lot of thought into this when I was department chair of Physics and we revised the undergraduate curriculum to required 1 quarter course in computer science as a lower division requirement. Our undergraduate electronics and senior labs use Labview. The most popular undergraduate elective is computational physics which teaches physics problems in C++ and the prerequisite is the CS intro course. Almost all physics graduates have some exposure to Mathematica, Labview and C++ and many have experience in their undergraduate research with Mathematica, Labview, or C++.

column152: I think computation for physics undergrads is important, but should be addressed via course taken in the computer science department.  too much emphasis on computation physics for UNDERGRADS leads to a decrease in basic analytical skills in the upper level courses. For example, I've seen my junior and senior students rely too much on MatLab for doing integrals that can be done by hand or a solution given in Gradshetyn.  As a result they get a wrong answer due to a numerical approximation rather than finding an exact result. While using computation can be illumination in terms of physical situations where exact results are impossible, I don't like decreasing the basic knowledge that undergrads need to have for glitzy simulations.  As seniors they start to find there are transcendental equations etc, and then the idea of numerical solutions begins to be important.  I think grad school is where the emphasis is to be placed.  Our job at the undergrad is to make sure the undergrads have some basic programming skills by requiring basic CS courses as part of the physics major, but keep the undergrad PHYSICS to exactly solvable problems.  They need to do regular boundary conditions before they can understand the need for more numerical approaches to more complicated situations.

They also complain that there was no programming prerequisite, even though I cover all the programming they need during class). 4. I do hope to get around to introducing computational physics someday, but maybe not until after I have tenure.

column152: Physics thinking has become moribund for almost century "math trumps everything". This is a seriously erroneous culture. Math, and hence computation, represents human invented logics, not creator's logics. But, our physics culture has been erroneously driven by the perception that if math works, validated by some experimental data  it represents a final theory. No scientific theory can be a "final theory". All theories must be challenged from the foundational postulates and up. See my book, "[Title]", CRC, 2014, by [Name].

column181: Current physics theories are taught as confirmed religions. All formal educational institutions, fund giving agencies, Knowledge gate-keeping publication organizations teach physics as formal religions that must not be questioned.   That is why I have published my book, "[Title]". I also run a biennial conference, "[Title]?" for out-of-box thining physicists. It has been successfully growing since 2005.

Along the way, I taught an undergrad numerical analysis course for computer science majors that included programming the algorithms they were learning and also helped run the classroom part of an REU program for many years.  My part was computational physics for the untrained masses, but I also had students who worked on individual projects with me. column62: I have created a set of computational physics lab for my [Class Name/Num] (Physics for Scientists and Engineers III) course.  The lab is once a week for 3 hours.  The students complete about 10 of these labs and become proficient beginners with Mathematica programming and some simple computational methods for solving physical problems.    I also have a small set of undergraduate students that do research with me which is highly computational.  I train and support their activity with a 64-core Linux server and with some basic programming techniques needed to do their research.
column114: Some students are vehemently against computational labs.  Some consider it "not physics" and object on "moral" grounds, sometimes even refusing to do the labs because they are only here "to learn physics" not computation.    Others are not morally opposed to it, but are also not interested and find it a nuisance.    I am still learning the best way to deal with this.  I try to give motivational discussions telling them why it is important and useful.  I also try to explain that it is required not only in this course but in the department and doing well in the computation in this course will benefit them in other courses.  But, I am still looking for ways to improve student receptiveness.

I instituted a computational project into junior level mechanics the first semester i taught.  Was stunned to find students did not understand programming at all, despite having grown up using computers.  I believe that ALL undergrad physics majors should have at least some exposure to line-level programming. column152: In the last 5 years we have developed a new sophomore-year course on computational methods, and have added a junior-year computational "lab" on to our quantum mechanics course. We are also adding computational and data reduction/manipulation courses to our graduate curriculum. BUT these courses are difficult to maintain, because not every faculty member uses the same tools or languages. A related problem is that our faculty don't want to teach basic programming, they want to teach physics. And while they may be willing to provide homework problems that involve programming, they don't want to teach the basic skills to our students, most of whom have never programmed in any language before joining the major.
column181: My university struggles to figure out how to teach basic programming skills to students in science and engineering. The tenured faculty find it tedious, even those in Computer Science. But once a student understands the basics, then we are happy to teach them the applications to physics problems.  Our best plan right now is to teach some basic fluency in algorithms (using Mathematica) during the fall of sophomore year, and then give them a full-fledged programming course, taught by the Physics department, in the spring of sophomore year. These skills are absolutely essential for the students, but we cannot water down the physics curriculum in order to teach them.

column41: Analysis of datasets
column62: I use both simulation and public datasets in undergraduate courses in physics and astronomy. For example, in introductory astrophysics, students build their own Hertzsprung-Russell diagrams using publicly-available Hipparcos stellar data. In advanced astrophysics, we utilize the publicly-available MESA code to develop stellar structure models. Students pursue a final project of their selection using MESA. Finally, in our advanced undergraduate lab, I lead a module where students measure Hubble's constant using publicly-available Type Ia supernovae data.

column62: In teaching introductory mechanics for physics majors I include a small number of assessments that require computation.  I use Matlab for examples, so almost all students use that as well even though I am open to them using any programming language.  The last time I taught this, I assigned one large group project to computationally model the dynamics of an initially stretched massive spring that is allowed to fall under the influence of gravity.  During the upcoming semester, I will instead assign a total of five homework problems spread through the semester that will utilize computational modelling.  Examples include the trajectory of a projectile in the presence of air drag (with both laminar and turbulent models of drag).
column114: There was some comment from students along the lines of 'this isn't a CS class.'  However, some students were enthusiastic and all students were game enough to seriously complete the assignment.
column115: Students have gained at least an introduction to using computation in physics.  The results from modelling the dynamics of a dropped massive spring were impressive as they matched experiments and could not have been determined analytically or intuitively.  This increased student acceptance of the utility of using computation.
column150: I will assign five problems involving computation rather than one larger project.  This will also allow me to provide great help with programming at the beginning of the semester, but dial it back considerably by the end.

column62: So much of the modern world's scientific understanding of the past, present, and future is based upon modelling!! I think it is crucial for students to understand & gain practical experience of how such computer models are constructed: the application of the 'known' physics etc, & how the model predictions can be way off if there is a 'trivial' programming error.

column151: We have no plans to change how or whether we are using computation in our undergraduate program.
column160: I didn't need it as an undergrad, so I didn't know it when I needed it in grad school, and didn't pick it up quickly enough when I got there.  It certainly contributed to my lack of success there.  When I dropped out of my PhD program with a master's degree I became a lab instructor.  I haven't needed much in the way of modern computational skills for my actual job.  I do research on the side, mostly during breaks (there's funding for the undergraduates but not for me), and for that I should improve my computational skills so I can work on more relevant problems (not that that's likely to fix the funding problem).  I find computer languages as hard to learn as other languages.  I'm not fluent in anything.  There's a huge start-up cost every time I go to do anything, presumably because I don't do it regularly.  I spend all my time on syntax and debugging and no time on physics.  I can't think of the last time that I solved a physics problem numerically with any significant confidence.

column62: Before I came to the [University], there was not a dedicated course on computational physics in the physics curriculum.  My earlier attempts to incorporate computational activities into other upper division courses, like classical mechanics, were only marginally successful, as many students had no prior background apart from some exposure to Excel.  As a result, they were unable to perform basic functions like plotting or root finding.  I developed a dedicated course on computational physics, and obtained administrative approval for its addition to the physics curriculum as an elective.  It has been offered once so far, and is slated to be offered every other year.
column114: The initial offering of the course was cancelled due to low enrollment.  Despite our institutional profile of graduating on average 5 physics majors per year, the department and college are unlikely to allow a course to run if it has fewer than 10 students, even for new courses.  This is a continual challenge with our upper division courses.  The computational physics course was subsequently added to a list of approved courses for engineering students to count towards their degree requirements.  As a result, the next offering of the course received an enrollment boost from engineering students, and was allowed to run.
column115: The program went from 0 dedicated computational courses and very little use of computation in the upper division curriculum, to offering a computational physics elective every other year.
column150: The elective course has only been offered one time.  Based on the feedback I received I am retooling certain aspects to meld better with student background and interests for the offering of the course next year.

column152: My baseline goal in adding computational components to physics classes it to create an empowered citizen.  Making students familiar with techniques to acquire data, manipulate and analyze it, and present results puts the tools to study the world into their hands.  This activity coupled with a "See for yourself" attitude towards investigation is critical to creating a generation of citizens that can reason confidently with regards to socio-politico-scientific complexity.  Specific to physics, the concepts of creating models and studying their behavior to see which mechanisms drive which effects is key gives citizens the ability to think through a problem in increasing degrees of specificity.
column160: I was first introduced to computation in a class where the professor put a FORTRAN dictionary in our hands and some simple problems.  Realizing that the tools to write software and solve problems were free and widely available was eye-opening.  I continued teaching myself new languages (C++ and Python) using resources available on the internet as I had the need in order to proceed with my doctoral work.  This was adequate, but I find that I am still fundamentally limited in my computer skills by a lack of formal concepts.  I would have benefitted from an undergraduate or graduate course rooted in the natural sciences but whose goals was to make computer science ideas more accessible.  Ideally something presented practical concepts and useful tools to aid thinking through and planning complicated software and eschewed the more esoteric matters that computer science itself is concerned with.

column150: The issue of using computation is that for classes, there is no time or interest to teach computational methods and the students are already struggling with the material so to add the learning of computation makes them frustrated.  Now in quantum class, I show simulations, but I do not have them generate their own for example with Mathematica or MatLab. I have been waiting for the situation where all the students in the course will have already completed our department computational requirement.  We are slowly moving in this direction with our computational physics course earlier in the curriculum plan. Then, I will have the ability to assign computational problems for example in advanced labs and in quantum class.  Right now, I assign only easy graphing that they can do on their calculators or with Excel.  This activity was not included in your broad definition of "computational". When the students are already familiar with the use of a package tool (for example Matlab) then I can assign computational problems to solve the Schrodinger equation in quantum class.  This can be used for both analytic and non-analytic situations.  My colleague who teaches E&M has expressed the same interest in giving the students more difficult charge configurations to solve using computation packages. If you narrow the computational definition to include only coding (C++, python, etc.) then I will likely never do that in a course.  It will not be in my teaching career that all the students in my classes have basic capability in coding.
column151: We are planning to add some computation into our undergraduate program.
column152: As mentioned in the previous comment box, the issue is to get all of the students trained in computational skills before they are required to use them in a class.  We do not have room to have even one or two students struggling with the computational aspect along with the physics.  Our approach to computational skills is the same as for math skills.  We teach a course to prepare the students in math skills needed for the upper level courses.  We are trying to move in that direction with our Computational Physics course to be taken earlier - in the second or third year - before the last year of the curriculum.  Then we can require the that the students have the skills to be put to use in other courses.  The computational physics course is not now a prerequisite for upper level courses.  I don't know if we will move to that officially, but as I said, we are trying to get the students taking the course earlier.  This year I will have students taking quantum and computational at the same time.  Maybe by next year, students in quantum  and E&M will have already taken the computational course and both instructors will be able to have computational homework problems.  Again, I define computational as using the packages like Mathematica and MatLab. Students are encouraged to take computer programming courses but are no longer required to do so.  Our computational physics course currently teaches problem solving using before Mathematica and now MatLab and they learn to modify C++ basic program routines, but they are not required to start from scratch.  The emphasis is on modeling and obtaining the solution to a physics problem using the computer.
column160: I learned some analytic computational skills for analyzing my thesis data, but my PhD was mostly hardware oriented with less need for simulations or computation. I modified existing code for analyzing my thesis data. For my current research, I am now learning on my own (with help from colleagues) to use large computational codes (GEANT and MCNP) for simulations and for example ROOT packages for analysis, which is not easy as a faculty member at a mostly teaching school.  I have also learned on my own to use Mathematica for simulations and such for demonstrations in class.  Over the years, I have also modified other people's code, teaching myself C, C++.  I am old enough that FORTRAN was still taught at my undergraduate institution.  I am not familiar with Python, but a number of people are trying to convince me that I need to learn that programming language.  As far as computational skills, I did take a numerical analysis course taught by the math department at my undergrad institution. Otherwise, I am taught by the postdocs and grad students that I work with and through modifying other people's code.
column166: This is the same question word for word as on the last page, so I do not understand what is being asked here. I will briefly describe my answer to the above question about using computation. As mentioned before, I am learning to use large scale code packages, GEANT and MCNP.  My intention is to start having my undergraduate students use the codes for simulations work.  Right now, they are doing hardware detectors work and will move toward simulations hopefully with me about one or two steps ahead of them.  I work in a group with colleagues who are wonderful about helping me learn these simulations codes and will be an asset for my students.

I've also invested huge amounts of time in trying to write automatic test suites that can give students immediate feedback on many aspects of their code as they develop it (first, using a unit testing framework with MATLAB, then writing my own introspection code for Mathematica, which was super-cool but darned near killed me). My typical load is 3-4 course equivalents per semester, so redesign just comes out of my own hide and research time.
column115: Almost every physics major we graduate takes both of our one-credit computational physics labs (which I teach), and they are generally quite popular except for the occasional student who "loathes programming" and gets a mental block about it. I've had a few students (which is a significant fraction of our very small program's output) get jobs or experience graduate school successes because of these courses.
column151: We have no plans to change how or whether we are using computation in our undergraduate program.
column152: We are a very small, very laissez-faire department that is chronically short on faculty lines and research due to several years of politically-motivated budget slashing. I can do pretty much anything I want with my courses, or even offer new ones, but there is nothing resembling "release time" or "resources" available to do so. My colleagues are open to discussions about altering our majors program in various ways, including possibly including more computation, but (a) we'd have to cut something, and that's hard to sell, and (b) there's no release time or resources to help anyone else pitch in.
column160: I've been a programming nerd since 7th grade, and always find ways to include computation in pretty much anything I do. When I took this faculty job, nobody "owned" the two computational physics labs, so I volunteered and have made them mine.
column181: It ought to be integrated more thoroughly into all other courses, but that's tough to do given the territorial inclinations of physics faculty and the fact that many are not qualified to or interested in design and teach computational aspects. Team teaching or similar models are tough when most of us regularly teach overloads and don't have adequate time for research. There's also the "how do I fit that in, too?" problem.

column62: I'm chairing my Department's Undergraduate Curriculum Committee, and we are trying to increase the use of computation throughout the core courses in the Physics major. Most recently, we have been trying to standardize our students' computational skill set so that all students are familiar with one language or computing platform that instructors can then use at all levels. Last year we began moving towards making Matlab the standard, but this year we are reconsidering that effort and thinking instead about making Python the standard. This is an ongoing discussion, but computing is definitely something that we are trying to strengthen in our curriculum ([University]).

column152: Computer-based teaching of basic physics is destructive.  Students need to learn that physics is about the real world.    Computer based simulations could just as well be simulating fictional physics.  Only after learning basic physics thoroughly, should students be exposed to computer simulations.  Of course, physics majors should learn computer methods to prepare them for careers in finance and big data.
column160: I started in 1960 as a junior high school student on an IBM 650 on Saturdays at IBM Watson Lab, [University]niversity, then on IBM 7090(?) at NASA Goddard Institute, [University]niversity.  I worked as a commercial computer consultant in the in 1979-80 late 1960s and early 1970s.  I wrote my physics phd thesis on a Vax unix machine at [University] in troff, one of the first physics papers to be computer typeset.  I've used computers in my research since 1983, using C, Perl, Python, and Sage.  I avoid Mathematica like the plague.  Students should be taught to avoid Mathematica.  It is a black box.  Science requires openness and verifiability.  If students are taught about math software, they should be pointed to Sage, which is open.  Sincerely, [Name]

column114: Total apathy from the department and the university. The university is interested only in teaching the engineers how to use the commercial packages, not how to code the practical science problems. The physics faculty mostly don't care, and have 'if you want to do it do it, but don't bother us' attitude. Two senior professors who have comp phys projects are interested only in work within their group, but don't put any effort into educating the undergrads. One of them teaches the only intro comp phy course in our department is taught at a ridiculously simple level - the students universally think they didn't learn anything in that class. My own teaching load is immense, and I can only introduce comp phy projects through the existing courses.
column115: I have regular computational projects in two advanced astrophysics courses that students generally say is by dar the most useful (and complex) computer programming experience they had during their studies.
column150: One of the astrophysics courses I teach will be modified to have a sequence of seven bi-weekly group computational projects closely following the course material. The analytical assignments will be given only as a part of the computational project, but the bulk of all HW assignments/projects will be computational. Some of the projects are designed to build up on the previously developed code. This is mostly driven by the studens' positive and encouraging feedback about the computational projects from the previous semesters. They have the obvious desire to learn copmp phy -- but that also requires close mentoring by the faculty, which I'm happy to provide.

column114: Broad student access to effective computation tools during class can be challenging (eg class too big for computational lab, or lab not available).    As student laptop usage and software availability has become more widespread, this can be done more easily.  However, new tradeoffs and challenges also come up with interactive personal computing during class time (distractions, Mac vs. PC, different hardware and software specs, technical & network errors & bugs).  A subset of students (~20%) really struggle with computational assignments. For a variety of reasons (incl. access, prior experience, peer networks) some of these students experience struggles they would not have without computational requirements.

column114: With the relatively large number of liberal-learning classes our students must take and a normal load of only 4 courses/semester, we can no longer require our majors (merely urge them) to take CS courses.  While we would like to offer a formal course focused on computational physics, we have so many other upper-level courses to offer and too few faculty or students to allow us to offer another, so the addition of a computational course would imply the loss of one in astrophysics, biophysics, condensed matter physics, geophysics or particle physics, all of which have been successful.  We have not overcome these issues yet, and unless a miracle happens, where we overcome both demographic trends and decreasing support for merit aid that would let us increase the number of our majors from ~16 back to >22/year, we won't.
column115: We have incorporated more computation in many upper-level classes and more faculty are supervising computationally intensive research projects. column152: The number of majors is declining, implying we will need to offer fewer upper-level courses, not more. Since students now have access to our campus license for Mathematica on their laptops, we will add more computational exercises to a range of mid-level and upper-level courses.  We hope to add some computation to our intro courses, but since many sections are taught by adjunct faculty, this will be non-uniform.
column160: As far as I know, my high school ([High School Name]) was the only (public) school that had a computer in 1968 when I took a programming course. I had to develop websites when I was working as a postdoc (2003) and so I had to learn by myself html and php. As of last year I decided to break free of the IDL license and I translated all my IDL libraries to python. Research-wise I am moving back from a model written in C to a model written in Fortran.

column152: You are asking me policy questions that I have no knowledge about---I am a retired engineer and a part time instructor. I am given the teaching guidelines that I must follow.   I am a graduate engineer and worked as an engineer for some time in a company that made seals to retain fluids for rotating and static mechanical applications.  I started as a research engineer and I developed specialized computer programs to solve non-linear differential equations. I had to develop my own finite element analysis programs to solve these problems. There were no "canned" programs available.  Today there are many computer programs that can be purchased (finite element analysis for example and drafting programs).  I do not know if CSN has any courses that teach students how to use these programs.  If not, perhaps CSN should consider adding them to their curriculum.   My work developing these computer programs helped me advance in the company and I eventually became an executive so I believe knowledge in the computational field is very useful.  This knowledge also helped me become a world class consultant in the field of fluid sealing after I retired from the company and moved to [City].

column62: I mostly work with undergraduates to use computation in research projects: most recently, by having them learn python to interact with data acquisition hardware over RS-232.  I work with them for some time outlining the projects and techniques required, and send them off to work on online tutorials and to write the code and come back with questions.  Overall, it hasn't been a particularly successful approach, I'm afraid.
column114: I've noticed over the past twenty years of interacting with students at multiple institutions that overall, students today come to physics with significantly fewer computing skills than in days past.  At my current institution in particular, I have not in six years ever had a student with prior programming experience, even in something as basic as Excel spreadsheets.  They start from a significant deficit relative to where my peers and I started in the early '90s  I spend significantly more time than is fruitful in training them in their first programming language, and have not yet succeeded in getting a single student to the point where they can actively and independently get a computer to talk to a piece of hardware in a compiled language, or even to write or modify a simple simulation program.  Just getting students in an advanced undergraduate lab to use Excel with some facility was like pulling teeth.  Let's not even mention getting to the point of "best practices" like version control, build systems, etc.  This is so far behind what my peers and I were doing on similar experiments 20 years ago, it's maddening and frustrating.  I can't say that I've overcome any of these issues, or even have an inkling of how to do so.  I would love to pull more significant computational work into the curriculum, but given how much we "have" to cover in an undergraduate sequence, it's hard to see how that would be possible.  It's quite a frustrating issue.

column150: I have a new cohort of students starting at the Sophomore level this year.  I plan to attempt (yet again) to incorporate some python scripting and excel work, particularly for visualization. column152: How can we get students to minimal computational competence in _any_ language or program without eviscerating the current physics content of the major?  How do you get a student from 0 to minimally competent without losing sight of the physics they are supposed to also be learning?  I can't have them take multiple courses in programming just to do their problem sets.
column160: I've been programming since I was ten.  I've taken multiple courses at the undergraduate and graduate level in programming languages, and numerical methods and analysis.  I'm also self-taught in multiple compiled and interpreted languages, and self-taught in a number of widely used physics computational software frameworks, both for simulation and data acquisition and control.
column181: I think a time will come soon where undergraduate curricula will _have_ to be updated to make computation a core component of the program.  We use it everywhere in the R&D side of the field, far more than we use all the manual analytic and approximation techniques we teach our students.  There is, however, significant resistance to modifying the basic curriculum that we've had with us for basically the last 100 years.  We need a compelling example of an overhauled curriculum that places more emphasis on computation while retaining the best of the current techniques.  Until a significant best-practice can be developed that can be shown to be superior to the current approach, I doubt that significant traction is going to be made in the teaching of undergraduate physics.  Heck, we've had data for literally _decades_ that the lecture style course _doesn't work_ for most of our students, and yet that style still predominates because the alternatives that work better are so much more work to get started with.  I fear that the teaching of computation is going to be stuck in the same rut for a long time to come.

column152: We are a small department at a small residential liberal arts college. We have no resources to teach general programming but we do train students to use some programs in the laboratory sections of introductory courses and in the advanced laboratory. Specifically we teach LaTeX, MATLAB, and Mathematica. The Math/CS department does not teach languages that we use. They teach Java and C++ primarily. Our faculty use MATLAB, IDL, Mathematica, and Python primarily, so we have to train our students ourselves but we have little time to do so.  I am not a programmer or a computational physicist  I'm a theorist. I value the results of computation but only insofar as it complements theoretical underpinnings. I have no desire to program nor a desire to have my students program for the sake of programming only. I do not want my department to spend too many of its resources on teaching programming especially if it would come at the expense of the core physics curriculum.
column160: My level of competence in computation is intentionally low, though I can usually hack my way through problems. (For instance, in the early 1990s in order to compile Maxima I first ported Austin-Kyoto Common Lisp to NEXTSTEP even though I barely knew the rudiments of C and did not know any Lisp at all. It took me a week when a skilled programmer probably could have done it in a couple of hours tops.) My experience in graduate school in the 1980s at Caltech of knowing researchers who started out being interested in lattice QCD who ended up leaving physics for field of parallel programming made me wary of becoming involved in computational physics. I saw the emphasis on computation grow and the emphasis on physics shrink. I worry about letting computational physics be emphasized within the curriculum at a small department.
column166: My most fruitful research collaboration has been with a phenomenologist and computational physicist (I'm a theorist). The reason that that was so fruitful was that the computational results were quite simple which forced us to look hard at the theory to try to tease out these simple approximate behaviors and then to use those to make the computational portion more elaborate.

column152: There are three problems with the survey.  First, there is no "N/A" or "Don't know" option.  This would have been the appropriate answer for some of the questions.  Second, the tone of the questions lead me to believe that the survey is looking for specific answers that promote computing.  To be sure, computing is a vital part of physics, and I could not do my work without it.  But I did not see a question such as "Do you feel that it is better to solve a problem by computation rather than analytically (including appropriate approximations in the analytic solution)?"  Finally, I am not familiar with all ongoing aspects of undergraduate education in my department.  As most departments have committees for this and that, one often doesn't know what is going on in each committee until it hits the department meeting stage.  Thus, there should have been a "Don't know" option.

column62: We have created a set of computational physics modules (as part of an AAC&U TIDES grant) to teach scientific computation at multiple levels.  We tried out the modules in the first few weeks of our introductory lab for majors, but found that the quick coverage of programming basics was overwhelming for the students (who had no prior experience), so now we will be dedicating a semester-long sophomore-level lab to computation, using our modules.  We also plan to distribute the more advanced modules throughout our junior/senior-level courses.  We hope this distributed exposure will help to maintain students' computational skills.  All seniors will be asked to submit a computational e-portfolio as part of our senior seminar  the portfolio will be the proof that they have attained the skill level we seek.

column114: The biggest difficulty in my department is figuring out what part of our curriculum to cut as we increase our focus on computation.  Do we require a complete course on computation, and if so, what course do we drop? (We can't increase the number of required courses.)  If we add computational components to existing courses, what content goes out?  Another challenge has been dealing with the great variety of majors that we have.  Some are headed to grad school in physical science/engineering and research careers, while others are "liberal arts" physics majors. The computational tools they will probably need in the future vary widely  settling on the common "core" that we can assume all upper-level physics students will have has not been trivial.  A third challenge is designing computational exercises that are suitable for a broad range of expertise.  We have students who are double-majoring in computer science, or have completed a summer of computational research, along with some who haven't become truly comfortable with computational tools by the end of the sophomore year.  The best exercises recognize this, with flexible "top ends," so that all students learn physics while increasing their computational abilities.
column115: Up to now, our department has chosen the incremental approach, i.e., we introduce computation into many courses, starting in the first and second year, with a focus on two tools: python and Mathematica.  Even though this not enough to turn our students into sophisticated users of computational tools, we do see success in the fact that we don't have to "start over" when we use computation in third and fourth year classes.

column62: I write all my lecture notes in Mathematica, including code-generated pictures.  I encourage the students to type their homework assignments into Mathematica and have provided template notebooks with Style sheets that allow them to have automatically numberrf sections and equations.  I also show them how to refer to equation and section numbers that automatically update when sections and equations are added.  Also, We talk about how to check their work with Mathematica's algebraic commands, although I require them to type full derivations, with English explanations for all the homework.  They are required to plot all their results and think about what the plots mean.
column114: The biggest barrier was convincing the university to get an unlimited site license for Mathematica.  We started out with buying individual copies, and convinced the university to get a limited license of 30 copies.  But we couldn't use it in classes because the students need to have it on their own computers.  We now have a state-wide unlimited license in cooperation with other universities in [State]  This license allows students, faculty and staff to have as many home licenses as they want for free, and we can have Mathematica on all the computer labs on campus.  This is the only way it is possible to be sure the students will use it.  By having it widespread, the users can all learn from each other.
column115: After taking my courses and using Mathematica, the students now use Mathematica in all their courses.
column150: I will continue to use Mathematica in all my courses.
column151: We are planning to add some computation into our undergraduate program.
column152: The most difficult part is convincing all the faculty members to include meaningful computational work in all the classes.  We are trying to convince everyone to incorporate Mathematica in all the courses, since we have an unlimited site license for that.  We have had some success, but there is no release time available for them to have time to learn how to use it.  The university talks a lot about incorporating technology in teaching, but they usually mean using clickers, whereas we want the students to be able to program in Mathematica and use it as a tool to help them understand physics better.  We think that this is better than answering multiple choice questions with clickers.
column160: I have learned how to program because I needed it to solve problems in my research, and I have found it to be very important in my teaching.  In Mathematica, I can have all my lecture notes, with mathematical derivations in good notation.  At any point in a notebook I can then do a computation, display a graph, and have animations and interactive graphics.  Before we had access to these tools, students would work out long derivations by hand and get a result but would not be able to think about the meaning of the result.  Now being able to do 3D graphics and manipulative graphics, they can realize the physical meaning of their derivations.  We have even found that this can be a check on the reliability of the results.  In the graduate electromagnetism course out of [University], the derivations are often very long and involved.  One can find solutions to some of these problems posted on the web.  Students found, for one of these problems, results posted at well-known universities, that were in conflict with each other and wanted to know which one was the correct solution.  By plotting the solution in three dimensions, they saw that one of the purported solutions did not satisfy the boundary conditions for the problem, but the other did.  This led to the discovery of the flaw in the arguments leading to the wrong solution.
column166: I will continue learning new computational methods by exploring all the new functionality incorporated into each new release of Mathematica. column181: We think that Mathematica is the best way for students to get involved in computational physics because it has so much functionality built in, and all the explanations can be written in the text cells in a notebook.  One does not have to spend so much time at the beginning writing many lines of code to calculate very simple things.

column114: The biggest obstacles are two: adding computation to a course adds a lot more material for students to learn, and because their backgrounds are so diverse, one cannot count on many of them knowing simple basics, like standard control structures or the concept of variable types. Second, the software landscape changes very rapidly, which makes it daunting to develop a standardized curriculum around a particular language or computing environment. Thus, we use a rather heterogeneous approach: some will use advanced techniques within, say, Mathematica, while others will do their best with Excel spreadsheets.
column115: Students in general were happy with learning to use computer methods to solve lab-related data problems. They also learned a useful skill.
column151: We have no plans to change how or whether we are using computation in our undergraduate program.
column152: Department-wide, the main challenge is coordination. column114: After adopting MATLAB and getting a site license, department members almost immediately started going in different directions, arguing that we should change to Python or Mathematica or Scilab. As department chair, I put my foot down. We were going to use MATLAB for five years, see how it went, and then decide if we want to change.   Only a motivated few faculty were really able to embed MATLAB in their curriculum. The lack of continuity means that each instructor can't assume that their student already know MATLAB basics. This leads to a lot of duplication of effort.  It would be best if students had a programming basics class before asking them to do computational physics. We require a single CompSci programming class, but students can take it whenever they want. It's not very useful in the physics curriculum  if they take after their second or third year.

column152: Our main considerations are the following:  (1) how do we guarantee that students have easy access to computations, in particular the issue of students with or without laptops, (2) how to choose our "standard" computational environment and whether or not this locks us in for all time, (3) how to schedule our computational elements among all of the different courses so that we're not constantly reteaching the introductory elements, (4) since we can't require more classes, what do we NOT teach in the courses we are currently covering?
